content:
ICS 1C HW 3 for Vula Baliotis

About Vula Baliotis

Name: Vula Baliotis
E-mail: easu1569@ea.oac.uci.edu
Major: English and psychology

Three neat Web finds:

  1. Being a full-blooded Greek who lives of bread, olive oil and feta cheese, I took it upon myself to look for a pita bread recipe. Pita bread is useful for so many Greek foods and seems manageable to make!
  2. Another neat thing I found in World Wide Web is a collection about poetry. Specifically, there is a section to click on that tells one all about the haiku. Click here to get haiku pleasure.
  3. A great way to take a break and get a few laughs is by looking at the Comic Relief page under the Christian religion section of the ElNet Galaxy. This is definitely something the pathologically philosophical could get a kick out of!

Questions I can now answer
  1. What is the relationship between a client and a server?
  2. What is HTML and what is its purpose?
  3. I want to apply to graduate school in English at the University of Washington. What are the admissions requirements?
  4. I want to do an independent study with a professor in the cognitive sciences department who is working with linguistics. Who does research in this field?
  5. I've heard a Sting version of a song called "Come Down in Time" but wasn't sure who wrote it or what the lyrics are. I want to find out this information

  1. What is the relationship between a client and a server?

    Clients and servers are agents, or programs, that work for a purpose--acting on behalf of something. A client is the software that allows users to access and browse the World Wide Web. Clients can display HTML pages in their desired format. They are refered to as browsers and respond to a user. Servers, on the other hand, are computers on which the Web documents reside and which runs HTTP software to permit Web transactions. Look into the various client software products and World-Wide Web server software products available for more information.

    Return to list of questions.

  2. What is HTML and what is its purpose?

     HTML stands for Hypertext Markup Language. One uses HTML to create a Web page. Web clients display HTML pages according to their coded format. HTML is a protocol designed specifically for the Web: any browser can read and display a written document that fits its needs, for html carefully defines the document for this purpose. The reason why html can be so versatile for browsers is that it expresses information in raw form, without consideration for formatting. For more information on html, go to the HTML Document Tutorial.

    Return to list of questions.

  3. I want to apply to graduate school in English at the University of Washington. What are the admissions requirements?

     The University of Washington Home Page is a good place to start on information about the university. There are photographs, descriptions about the university in specific, and about the surrounding environment. The University of Washington also includes graduate school entrance policies. A student must have a strong GPA (averaging a 3.00 or above) and should have high scores on both the general and English subject GRE tests. Also, the student should be able to display consistency in having completed her undergraduate program. For information on fellowships, traineeships, and scholarships offered during the admission process, click here.

    Return to list of questions.

  4. I want to do an independent study with a professor in the cognitive sciences department who is working with linguistics. Who does research in this field?

     A couple of professors in the school of social sciences do research in linguistics. A good way to start one's search is by getting a broad view on who the professors in the cognitive science department are. In this search, one can also find descriptions of each professor's research areas. The two professors who conduct research in linguistics are as follows: professor Barbara Landau, who works with spatial knowledge and language learning, and professor Mary Louise Kean, who works with linguistic theory and biological foundations of higher mental processes.

    Return to list of questions.

  5. I've heard a Sting version of a song called "Come Down in Time" but wasn't sure who wrote it or what the lyrics are. I want to find out this information.

     Bernie wrote this song, and Sting re-did it. Press on the song title to get Sting's introduction on why he chose to cover this song as well as to get a look at the lyrics: Come Down in Time. For more information on numerous lyrics, images and sounds by Sting, press here. For all of you die-hard Sting fans, would you like to get a look at real Sting photographs and album covers on your screen? Sting images will get him there!

    Return to list of questions.

Submitted January 30, 1995 for ICS 1C
